results_summary: Real rTMS significantly reduced spasticity (measured by the modified Ashworth scale) compared to sham treatment, but no differences were observed in secondary outcomes like walking test performance or quality-of-life scores.
population_specificity: Eight patients (mean age 38.5 years, 50% women) with hereditary spastic paraplegia.
study_duration: Intervention duration was not explicitly stated, but assessments were done before, immediately after, and 1 month post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of Basic Body Awareness Therapy (BBAT) versus standard care in improving pain during walking and daily functioning in people with hip osteoarthritis (HOA).
results_summary: BBAT did not significantly reduce pain or improve daily functioning compared to standard care, but it significantly improved movement quality. Per-protocol analysis showed benefits in self-efficacy, health, and function for participants with high compliance.
population_specificity: Community-living adults with hip osteoarthritis (HOA).
effective_dosage: 12 sessions of BBAT offered once a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether multicomponent physical activity (including brisk walking) and nutritional supplementation could improve muscle size, quality, and functional outcomes in older adults.
results_summary: The study found that the physical activity program led to significant improvements in walking speed (13%) and SPPB performance (38%), but these changes were not associated with changes in muscle size or quality. Nutritional supplementation did not enhance the effects of physical activity.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling seniors aged 70 years and older (77 ± 5 years).
effective_dosage: 3 times weekly brisk walking, muscle-strengthening, and balance training for 6 months; nutritional supplement (20 g whey protein + 800 IU vitamin D) or placebo daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of walking, independent of diet and weight-loss, on lipids and lipoproteins in women with overweight and obesity.
results_summary: Meta-analyses of 21 interventions demonstrated that exclusive walking improves total cholesterol and LDL levels in women with overweight and obesity, suggesting it can be used as a non-pharmacologic therapy.
population_specificity: Women with overweight or obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of non-immersive VR-based serious games versus conventional balance training on clinical, gait, and postural outcomes in individuals with total knee replacement.
results_summary: The study found significant within-group improvements in clinical, gait, and postural outcomes for both groups, but no significant between-group differences except for stance time of the affected limb, which improved more in the VR group. VR-based training was not superior to conventional therapy but could be considered an alternative rehabilitation approach.
population_specificity: 56 individuals with unilateral total knee replacement.
effective_dosage: 15 sessions (45 minutes each, 5 times per week).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical evolution of Covid-19 survivors, including motor function (assessed via walking tests), one year after hospital discharge.
results_summary: The study found that 25.8% of subjects had some degree of motor impairment, but motor function improved between 4 and 12 months post-discharge, as measured by the 2-minute walking test.
population_specificity: 200 previously hospitalized Covid-19 pneumonia patients from 2020.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a low-impact moderate-intensity exercise program could reduce fatigue and improve functional health outcomes in older adults with multimorbidity.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significant reductions in fatigue and frailty, along with improvements in physical activity, exercise tolerance, and mood, with sustained effects at follow-up. The exercise program was more effective than health education alone.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults with multimorbidity (mean age 78.1 years, 83.8% female).
effective_dosage: Thrice-weekly low-impact stepping exercises, progressively increased from low to moderate intensity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the long-term outcomes of surgical treatments for pediatric cervical kyphosis, focusing on fusion status, spine growth, instability, and neurological function.
results_summary: The study found that surgical interventions improved preoperative deformity and neurological status in pediatric patients with cervical kyphosis, with no impairment in growth or instability observed during follow-up, though complications were noted in syndromic patients.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients (6 months to 16 years) with cervical kyphotic deformity, including syndromic and non-syndromic cases.
study_duration: Variable follow-up periods, ranging from 1 to 35 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the reliability and validity of the MD Anderson Symptom Inventory (MDASI) for assessing symptom burden and functional status, including walking interference, in older Chinese cancer patients.
results_summary: The study found that moderate to severe interference with walking on the MDASI accurately indicated poor performance status and lack of independence in Activities of Daily Living, with an area under the curve of 0.7969 and 0.8304, respectively.
population_specificity: Chinese patients with cancer aged 65 years and older (n = 779, divided into younger [65-74 years] and older [75-84 years] groups).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how serum neurofilament light chain (S-NfL) levels, alone or combined with clinical classifications, predict disease progression milestones (including walking-aid usage) in later stages of Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: Higher S-NfL levels were significantly associated with reaching disease progression milestones like walking-aid usage (HR 3.5). Combined models of S-NfL and clinical factors improved prognostic accuracy for these milestones compared to S-NfL alone.
population_specificity: 85 patients with Parkinson's disease (average disease duration: 7.9±5.1 years).
study_duration: Observational follow-up period of 8.2±2.0 years between examinations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate sensorimotor outcomes in adults with adrenomyeloneuropathy, focusing on differences in disease progression between men and women, using quantitative measures like walking velocity and postural sway.
results_summary: The study found significant worsening in postural sway, sensation, and strength over 2 years, with walking velocity declining significantly in men but not women. Quantitative measures like walking velocity and postural sway were effective in tracking disease progression.
population_specificity: Adults with adrenomyeloneuropathy (61 men and 87 women, average age 46 ± 12 years).

study_goal: To determine the effects of whole-body vibration therapy on gait in chronic stroke patients compared to routine physiotherapy.
results_summary: Both whole-body vibration therapy and routine physiotherapy significantly improved walking speed in chronic stroke survivors, with no statistically significant difference between the two treatments.
population_specificity: Chronic stroke patients
effective_dosage: Whole-body vibration therapy: 3mm amplitude, 20Hz frequency, 5 bouts of 120 seconds with 60s rest intervals, 6 days/week

study_goal: To determine the optimal frequency of whole-body vibration training for improving balance and physical performance in older people with chronic stroke.
results_summary: High-frequency (26 Hz) vibration training improved performance in the five-repetition sit-to-stand test and timed-up-and-go test compared to zero-frequency training, while low-frequency (13 Hz) training only improved the sit-to-stand test. No significant improvements were observed in balance or walking speed.
population_specificity: Seniors with chronic stroke.
effective_dosage: 10 sessions of side-alternating WBV training at 13 Hz (low-frequency), 26 Hz (high-frequency), or 0 Hz (control).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of conducting a practice incremental shuttle walk test (ISWT) on patients' confidence in walking and managing breathlessness, and whether this confidence change influenced performance.
results_summary: Confidence in walking at home, managing breathlessness, and performing an ISWT improved significantly after a practice ISWT, though this confidence boost did not correlate with changes in walking performance. A statistically significant improvement in ISWT distance was observed between the practice and second test.
population_specificity: 100 patients with chronic respiratory disease (mean age 68.0 ± 10.3 years, 49% male, 63% with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of treadmill-desk interventions on energy expenditure, sitting time, and cardiometabolic health in adults with sedentary occupations.
results_summary: Treadmill desks significantly increased energy expenditure and metabolic rate in laboratory settings and reduced sitting time in workplace settings, but no significant changes were observed in blood pressure or other metabolic outcomes.
population_specificity: Adults with sedentary occupations (351 participants across 13 studies).

study_goal: To compare the effectiveness of two different exercise-based programs (strength exercises and breathing exercises) through telerehabilitation in patients with acute COVID-19.
results_summary: Both strength and breathing exercise groups showed significant improvements in fatigue, dyspnea, perceived effort, and physical state compared to the control group, with the greatest benefits in dyspnea and aerobic capacity observed in the breathing exercises group.
population_specificity: Patients with acute COVID-19 (mean age 39.40 ± 11.71).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to validate the accuracy of mHealth devices in estimating step counts for individuals with Parkinson's Disease compared to a standard criterion measure.
results_summary: The study found moderate to high correlations between mHealth devices (Google Fit, STEPZ, Fitbit Inc.®, Pacer, and Health) and the criterion-standard measure for step counting in individuals with PD, with Google Fit and STEPZ showing the strongest associations.
population_specificity: 34 individuals with idiopathic Parkinson's Disease (82% men, Hoehn and Yahr mean of 2.3 ± 1.3).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of preoperative exercise intervention on rehabilitation outcomes before total knee arthroplasty (TKA).
results_summary: The study found that preoperative exercise improved knee flexion, quadriceps strength, WOMAC scores, standing and walking test performance, and quality of life in TKA patients compared to controls. The results were statistically significant and clinically meaningful.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing total knee arthroplasty (TKA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of walking/running, cycling, or swimming for treating or preventing nonspecific low back pain (LBP).
results_summary: Walking/running was less effective than alternate interventions for reducing pain and disability in the short and medium term but slightly more effective than minimal/no intervention for treating chronic/recurrent LBP. High-certainty evidence supported these findings for disability reduction, while low-certainty evidence supported pain reduction.
population_specificity: Adults with chronic/recurrent nonspecific low back pain (2362 participants across 19 trials).
study_duration: Short-term and medium-term (exact durations not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the use of clinically accessible neuromodulatory approaches for functional restoration, including walking, in individuals with spinal cord injury (SCI).
results_summary: The study found that noninvasive neuromodulatory approaches combined with training show encouraging early evidence for improving walking function and reducing secondary complications in SCI, though larger studies are needed for clinical applicability.
population_specificity: Individuals with spinal cord injury (SCI).

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the efficacy of different bleaching agents for internal bleaching of endodontically treated discolored teeth.
results_summary: The study found that internal bleaching significantly changed tooth shade, with carbamide peroxide, hydrogen peroxide, and sodium perborate mixed with hydrogen peroxide showing better effects than sodium perborate alone. The risk of bias in the included studies was moderate to high.
population_specificity: Endodontically treated discolored teeth.
effective_dosage: Carbamide peroxide (35% or 37%), hydrogen peroxide (35%), sodium perborate mixed with hydrogen peroxide (3% or 30%).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of low-intensity resistance training combined with blood flow restriction (LIRTBFR) on muscle strength, muscle mass, and functionality in rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and osteoarthritis (OA) patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in muscle strength or functionality between LIRTBFR, moderate-intensity resistance training (MIRT), and high-intensity resistance training (HIRT). However, LIRTBFR showed similar muscle mass gains compared to HIRT and greater muscle strength improvements compared to low-intensity resistance training without blood flow restriction (LIRT).
population_specificity: Predominantly women with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and osteoarthritis (OA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the incidence, risk factors, and clinical outcomes of secondary hip fractures (SHFs) following nailing fixation for femoral fractures, with a focus on walking ability recovery.
results_summary: The study found a 0.7% incidence of SHFs, with poorer walking ability recovery in patients with secondary trochanteric fractures (20%) compared to femoral neck fractures (50%). The absence of femoral head fixation was significantly associated with SHF risk.
population_specificity: Patients aged >60 years who underwent nailing fixation for femoral fractures (n=2,293).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether high-flow nasal cannula oxygen therapy (HFNC) improves exercise tolerance better than standard oxygen therapy (SOT) in patients with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) during walking.
results_summary: The study found that HFNC improved exercise tolerance more effectively than SOT in IPF patients with exertional desaturation, likely due to changes in ventilatory mechanics and muscle oxygenation.
population_specificity: IPF patients (71.7 years old on average, 90% male) with exertional oxygen desaturation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether high-dose preoperative dexamethasone reduces postoperative pain and improves recovery in patients undergoing total knee arthroplasty (TKA).
results_summary: High-dose dexamethasone significantly reduced moderate-to-severe pain during walking at 24 hours postoperatively (49% vs. 79%) and improved pain at leg raise at 24 and 48 hours, along with reduced C-reactive protein levels and enhanced Quality of Recovery-15 scores.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing total knee arthroplasty (TKA).
effective_dosage: High-dose intravenous dexamethasone (1 mg/kg) compared to intermediate dose (0.3 mg/kg).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the impact of bypass surgery, endovascular treatment, and best medical treatment on quality of life and walking capacity in patients with disabling intermittent claudication.
results_summary: Bypass surgery showed significantly greater improvements in physical functioning, walking distance, and pain scores compared to best medical treatment, with similar efficacy to endovascular treatment. Bypass surgery also demonstrated better long-term primary patency rates and ABI improvement compared to endovascular treatment.
population_specificity: Patients with disabling intermittent claudication refractory to best medical treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the long-term effects of comprehensive spasticity treatment, including selective dorsal rhizotomy (SDR), on walking and related outcomes in individuals with spastic cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The study found that spasticity was effectively reduced in the Yes-SDR group, with no meaningful differences in most measures except for improved gait and maintained walking speed compared to the No-SDR group, which saw a decline. However, the Yes-SDR group required more subsequent orthopedic surgeries and antispastic injections.
population_specificity: Children with spastic cerebral palsy, assessed into young adulthood (age ≥21 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the incidence, risk factors, and clinical outcomes of intraoperative fractures (IFs) in patients undergoing cephalomedullary nailing (CMN) for trochanteric fractures, particularly focusing on the role of CT in detecting IFs.
results_summary: The study found an 11.8% incidence of IFs, with 8.3% being occult (detected only by CT). Patients with IFs had lower rates of regaining independent mobility at 3 months (69.6% vs. 79.1%), but no reoperations were required. Inadequate reduction on anteroposterior radiographs was the only significant risk factor for IFs.
population_specificity: 638 patients undergoing CMN fixation for trochanteric fractures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify predictors of non-response in functional capacity (measured by 6-minute walking distance) to pulmonary rehabilitation in COPD patients.
results_summary: 80% of patients showed clinically significant improvement in 6MWD post-PR. Predictors of lesser improvement included older age, longer pre-PR 6MWD, higher pre-PR dyspnea score, and oxygen therapy use.
population_specificity: COPD patients admitted to an inpatient pulmonary rehabilitation center.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the psychological and physical well-being, residual abilities, reintegration, and social inclusion of stroke survivors undergoing home rehabilitation, including walking-related outcomes.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant improvements in functional outcomes (e.g., walking tests, balance scales) immediately after rehabilitation, but a significant worsening at 3-month follow-up, except for depression scores which improved consistently.
population_specificity: 73 persons with chronic stroke disabilities.
effective_dosage: Home rehabilitation therapy twice a week for 40 sessions per year.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of conservative interventions (gait training and mechanical devices) on modifying foot progression angle (FPA) in children and adults with orthopedic and neurological diseases.
results_summary: Gait training was significantly more effective than mechanical interventions in modifying FPA towards in-toeing for knee osteoarthritis patients, improving pain. Results were inconclusive for neurological patients, with effectiveness dependent on patient-specific impairments and device properties.
population_specificity: Children and adults with orthopedic (e.g., knee osteoarthritis) and neurological diseases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility of a walking intervention (SystemCHANGE™ + activity tracker) compared to an activity tracker alone in improving physical activity adherence and cardiovascular outcomes in older kidney transplant recipients.
results_summary: The intervention group showed high adherence (96.5%) and within-group improvements in blood pressure, but both groups experienced a decrease in average daily steps over time, suggesting the need for additional boosters during maintenance.
population_specificity: Older kidney transplant recipients (age 60 and older).
effective_dosage: Not specified (activity tracker use was monitored).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of unexpected balance perturbation training using mechatronic shoes on dynamic balance and gait velocity in chronic ABI participants.
results_summary: Dynamic balance improved significantly post-training, with 45.7% of participants meeting or exceeding minimal detectable change. Gait velocity also improved significantly, though fewer participants (9.5%) exceeded the minimal detectable change.
population_specificity: Chronic ABI participants (stroke and traumatic brain injury)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association of cardiac rehabilitation (including walking) with all-cause mortality and functional outcomes in heart failure patients.
results_summary: Inpatient cardiac rehabilitation improved functional capacity (6-minute walking distance increased significantly) and was associated with reduced long-term mortality in heart failure patients.
population_specificity: 3219 patients with heart failure, divided into those directly transferred from acute care (CR-group 1) and those admitted from the community (CR-group 2).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess compliance and acceptability of a home-self-managed exercise program (including walking) in patients with vertebral fractures due to osteoporosis.
results_summary: 62.86% of patients were compliant with the program, which led to significant reductions in lumbar pain, improved posture, better quality of life, and enhanced physical performance in a 20 m walking test. Non-compliance was primarily due to lack of supervision, time, or motivation.
population_specificity: Patients with vertebral fractures due to osteoporosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare early postoperative patient-reported symptoms and functioning, including walking, between thoracoscopic segmentectomy and lobectomy for small-sized peripheral non-small-cell lung cancer.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in the impairment of walking or other functional items between thoracoscopic segmentectomy and lobectomy groups during the 6-day postoperative hospitalization and 4-week post-discharge period.
population_specificity: Patients with peripheral non-small-cell lung cancer ≤ 2 cm who underwent thoracoscopic segmentectomy or lobectomy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how ankle joint deficits and targeted interventions influence walking ability in children with cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The study found that ankle function significantly contributes to walking ability in children with cerebral palsy, with most targeted interventions demonstrating benefits. However, higher-powered or controlled studies are needed to confirm these findings.
population_specificity: Children with cerebral palsy

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate longitudinal changes in gait function and mediolateral stability after acute unilateral vestibular neuritis (uVN) to inform precise rehabilitation planning.
results_summary: Walking speed and step width in uVN patients improved significantly over time, with mediolateral stability (measured by IA variability) also showing significant improvement by the third test. Gait function and stability continued to improve beyond the acute stage of uVN.
population_specificity: 23 participants with unilateral vestibular neuritis (uVN) and 20 controls.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (gait analysis, not a supplement/dosage study).
study_duration: Three gait analyses conducted at monthly intervals after uVN onset.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Baduanjin exercise improves motor function in patients with post-stroke cognitive impairment (PSCI).
results_summary: The Baduanjin group showed significantly better improvements in limb motor function, balance, muscle strength, and gait parameters (step length, walking speed, cadence) compared to the control group. No adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: Patients with post-stroke cognitive impairment (PSCI).
effective_dosage: Not specified (Baduanjin training in addition to health education).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the efficacy of sling exercise therapy (SET) on improving walking ability in post-stroke patients.
results_summary: SET was found to be more effective than conventional physical therapy or trunk training in improving walking ability, including metrics like walking speed, muscle activity, functional ambulation, and step length. The pooled analysis supported SET's positive effects on multiple walking-related outcomes in post-stroke patients.
population_specificity: Post-stroke patients (1504 participants across 25 randomized controlled trials, primarily from China and South Korea).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to update the evidence on the association between slow walking speed and mortality, expanding current knowledge.
results_summary: The study found a consistent association between walking speed and all-cause mortality, supporting its use as a predictor of mortality in clinical practice. The analysis included 120,838 patients and over 25,148 deaths across multiple studies.
population_specificity: Patients from studies included in the systematic review (specific demographics not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of the polyherbal nutraceutical Tregocel® on physical functionality, particularly walking distance and related indices, in individuals with mild knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in walking distance (0.72 m per week), reductions in WOMAC indices (stiffness, daily functioning, global outcome), and enhanced leg flexion over 36 weeks of nutraceutical use.
population_specificity: Individuals with symptomatic, mild knee osteoarthritis (n = 107, 59.7 ± 10.8 yrs, 68.2% female).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a 16-week walking intervention on gait velocity and other gait parameters in older adults residing in long-term care homes, compared to interpersonal interaction and care-as-usual control groups.
results_summary: The walking group showed significant improvement in gait velocity compared to both control groups, but no significant differences were observed in stride length, cadence, or heel-to-heel base of support.
population_specificity: Older adults residing in long-term care homes with limited physical functioning.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the beneficial effects of walking and other physical activities on cardiovascular prevention and risk factor management.
results_summary: Walking and other physical activities were found to improve cardiovascular risk factors (e.g., hypertension, diabetes, obesity) and delay organ damage, with potential protective effects against atrial arrhythmias like atrial fibrillation.
population_specificity: General population and patients with cardiovascular diseases, including coronary artery disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a graded walking protocol and biweekly monitoring in increasing aerobic exercise duration to 150 minutes per week in elderly individuals with chronic disease.
results_summary: The treatment group showed significantly higher adherence to exercise recommendations (41.6% vs. 0%) and favorable improvements in heart rate response and physical activity levels, though no significant differences were observed in heart rate, blood pressure, or BMI changes between groups.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals (≥60 years) with multiple chronic conditions.
effective_dosage: Graded walking protocol (specific details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether visual-related interventions improve balance and walking ability in healthy older adults.
results_summary: Visual-related training generally improved balance and walking ability in healthy older adults, particularly when involving mobility-related movement components or as part of multi-component training. The clinical effectiveness and feasibility of such interventions require further investigation.
population_specificity: Healthy older adults aged 60 or above.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to outline the relevant history and examination areas for assessing gait abnormalities and their underlying causes in patients with neuromuscular pathologies.
results_summary: The study discusses the importance of evaluating factors like posture, walking aids, and footwear to identify specific gait patterns and generate provisional diagnoses. It emphasizes that gait examination from initial observation helps clinicians focus on relevant systems for further investigation and treatment.
population_specificity: Patients with neuromuscular pathologies presenting with gait abnormalities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of standard medical care versus unsupervised aerobic exercise (including walking) combined with standard care on cardiometabolic health and quality of life 30 days after bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of walking, only mentioning the comparison between the two intervention groups.
population_specificity: Bariatric surgery patients (n=14, age: 42.3 ± 2.5 years, BMI: 45.1 ± 2.5 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if an adductor canal block administered 20 hours after total knee arthroplasty improves postoperative pain and functional outcomes, including walking ability.
results_summary: The adductor canal block significantly reduced pain scores and opioid requirements within the first 24 hours and improved quadriceps strength, but these effects were not sustained beyond 24 hours. No increase in fall risk was observed.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing primary total knee arthroplasty.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of interventions, including walking, to increase physical activity levels in Gulf Cooperation Council countries and their impact on anthropometry and cardiovascular risk.
results_summary: Pedometer-based programs encouraging step counting and walking significantly increased physical activity, with step counts rising by 757 to 3,853 steps/day. Multi-component lifestyle interventions showed limited evidence for increased physical activity but improved outcomes like body weight and blood lipid levels.
population_specificity: Adults and children in Gulf Cooperation Council countries (Bahrain, Kuwait, Oman, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, United Arab Emirates), including higher-risk individuals (e.g., those with obesity or type 2 diabetes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the outcomes of midline structure preservation (MSP) versus conventional laminectomy (CL) in decompression surgery for lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS), focusing on functional recovery, pain, and patient satisfaction.
results_summary: The study found that MSP resulted in significantly less back pain, better functional recovery (e.g., longer walking distance at 6 months), higher patient satisfaction, and lower instability rates compared to CL. No significant differences were observed in leg pain, hospital stay, or certain functional scores between the two groups.
population_specificity: Patients with lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS) undergoing decompression surgery (540 in MSP group, 538 in CL group).
study_duration: Follow-up included outcomes measured at 3 days, 6 months, and unspecified longer-term periods.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the utility of the SARC-F screening tool for identifying sarcopenia and frailty in elderly populations.
results_summary: The SARC-F screening tool correlates well with clinical outcomes in the elderly and various underlying diseases, though it has low sensitivity for sarcopenia. The study highlights its usefulness in daily practice despite its limitations.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals with multiple comorbidities, dementia, and risk of sarcopenia and frailty.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the radiographic and clinical outcomes of the Petit-Morel method for treating developmental hip dysplasia in toddlers, focusing on avascular necrosis rates, acetabular dysplasia, and medium-term clinical outcomes.
results_summary: The study found low rates of avascular necrosis (3%) and residual acetabular dysplasia, with 17 of 18 hips followed to skeletal maturity classified as Severin Class I. The method provided good clinical and radiological outcomes, though overcorrection of the VCE angle was associated with walking-related pain in adulthood.
population_specificity: Toddlers (mean age 19±4 months) with developmental hip dysplasia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to update the evidence on the benefits of microprocessor-controlled prosthetic knees (MPKs) for limited community ambulators with transfemoral amputation.
results_summary: The study found that MPKs reduced falls, improved mobility, and enhanced patient perception in limited community ambulators. The analysis included 13 research projects with high overall validity.
population_specificity: Limited community ambulators with transfemoral amputation (704 out of 2366 patients).

study_goal: To explore the experience and acceptability of an exoskeleton-based physiotherapy program for non-ambulatory patients during subacute stroke rehabilitation from the perspective of patients and therapists.
results_summary: Patients with stroke viewed exoskeleton-based physiotherapy highly favorably, attributing greater opportunity and benefit to using the device during subacute rehabilitation. Therapists noted learning challenges and implementation barriers but acknowledged the potential for higher duration and more repetitious walking practice.
population_specificity: Non-ambulatory patients with subacute stroke and their physiotherapists.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect of a 24-month supplementation with a dietary supplement formula (Neuroaspis) on parameters associated with daily living activities, including walking, in patients with multiple sclerosis.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of the supplement on walking, but it suggests that polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs) may improve clinical outcomes in MS patients, warranting further investigation.
population_specificity: Patients with multiple sclerosis (MS)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of different AFO-wearing times (6-12 hours vs. 12-24 hours per day) on body functions, activity levels, and parental satisfaction in children with spastic CP.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in balance, spasticity, or ankle dorsiflexion between the groups, but the 6-12 hour group showed superior quality of life, daily living activities, fatigue reduction, and parental satisfaction. Prolonged AFO-wearing time negatively correlated with activity-participation levels and satisfaction.
population_specificity: Children with spastic cerebral palsy (Gross Motor Function Classification System I-III; mean age 7.3 ± 3.9 years).
effective_dosage: 6-12 hours per day vs. 12-24 hours per day of AFO usage.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the relationship between bone density, oral function, and physical performance (including walking speed) in older adults.
results_summary: The study found no significant association between walking speed and bone density, though other physical performance measures (e.g., one-leg standing) and oral function (e.g., occlusal force) were linked to bone density.
population_specificity: 754 older adults (aged 65+) living independently in rural regions, not taking osteoporosis medications.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of an 8-week supervised therapeutic exercise program on musculoskeletal health, gait kinematic parameters, functional capacity, and quality of life in adult patients with haemophilia.
results_summary: The exercise program significantly improved joint health, gait parameters, functional capacity, and quality of life in patients with haemophilia, though these gains were not maintained at the 6-month follow-up.
population_specificity: Adult patients with haemophilia (n=19, exercise group=10, control group=9).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the acute effects of light-intensity walking breaks versus moderate-to-vigorous exercise on cardiometabolic risk markers in patients with rheumatoid arthritis.
results_summary: Light-intensity walking breaks (BR) reduced postprandial glucose by 28% (AUC) compared to prolonged sitting (SIT), showing comparable or superior effects to moderate-to-vigorous exercise (EX) on some cardiometabolic markers. Additional metabolic and muscle-level changes were assessed but not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: 15 women with rheumatoid arthritis.
effective_dosage: 3-minute bouts of light-intensity walking every 30 minutes of sitting.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of progressive aerobic exercise (PAE) on fatigue, walking ability, and quality of life in people with multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: PAE led to a clinically relevant reduction in fatigue impact but showed small effects on walking ability and no significant effects on quality of life.
population_specificity: People with multiple sclerosis (pwMS)
effective_dosage: Two supervised sessions per week; 30-60 minutes, 65-95% of maximum heart rate

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of intradialytic exercise (including aerobic and resistance training) in improving physical function in advanced-age patients undergoing hemodialysis.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant improvements in the Short Physical Performance Battery score in the exercise group compared to the control group, but no significant differences in lower extremity muscle strength or 10-m walking speed.
population_specificity: Advanced-age patients undergoing hemodialysis (n = 101, aged not specified).
effective_dosage: Aerobic exercise at a target Borg score of 13 for 20 minutes, plus resistance exercises (three sets of 10 exercises at moderate intensity) using elastic tubing, performed three times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effect of Tai Chi (not Walking) on cardiac function in patients with myocardial infarction and provide evidence for choosing cardiac rehabilitation exercises.
results_summary: The study does not report results for Walking; it focuses on Tai Chi's effects on cardiac function, exercise tolerance, and quality of life in myocardial infarction patients.
population_specificity: 272 patients with myocardial infarction, randomized into control and experimental groups.
effective_dosage: Not specified for Walking (Tai Chi dosage not detailed in abstract).
study_duration: 24 weeks of intervention with a 3-month follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize evidence on the effectiveness of place-based interventions, including walking routes, on health outcomes and health inequalities.
results_summary: The study found tentative evidence that walking routes and other physical environment interventions can positively impact health outcomes, particularly physical activity, but effects on health inequalities remain unclear due to lack of equity data.
population_specificity: High-income countries (general population, no specific demographic details provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the clinical and echocardiographic outcomes of isolated transcatheter tricuspid valve repair (ITTVR) for significant tricuspid regurgitation (TR), focusing on improvements in NYHA functional class and 6-minute walking distance.
results_summary: Patients undergoing ITTVR showed significant improvements in NYHA functional status and 6-minute walking distance (from 237 ± 113 m to 294 ± 105 m) and a significant reduction in TR severity at mid-term follow-up.
population_specificity: Adults with significant (moderate or greater) tricuspid regurgitation, mean age 77 ± 8 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether ATOS (automated titrated oxygen during walking) improves walking endurance time in patients with hypoxaemia and severe COPD.
results_summary: The study found that ATOS led to significant, clinically relevant improvements in walking endurance time and SpO₂ levels compared to exercise-titrated CFOS.
population_specificity: Patients with hypoxaemia and severe COPD (median age 66 years, FEV₁ 30% predicted).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between olanzapine treatment and somnambulism (sleepwalking), particularly in a patient with treatment-resistant anorexia nervosa, and to review existing literature on olanzapine-induced somnambulism.
results_summary: The study reported a case of somnambulism re-exacerbation in a patient with anorexia nervosa after low-dose olanzapine administration and identified 8 other cases of olanzapine-related somnambulism in psychiatric disorders. It concluded that large-scale pharmacovigilance studies are needed to assess incidence and prevalence.
population_specificity: Patient with treatment-resistant anorexia nervosa and a systematic review of cases involving psychiatric disorders (schizophrenia and bipolar disorder).
effective_dosage: Low dose of olanzapine (specific amount not stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of mobile phone text-messaging exercise instructions (focused on walking and functional leg exercises) on body composition, cardiometabolic risk markers, and self-reported health in stroke patients at 3 months post-intervention.
results_summary: Both intervention and control groups showed favorable changes in fat-free mass and fat mass, as well as improvements in cholesterol-related biomarkers, but no significant between-group differences were observed. Self-reported health was high in both groups (94% and 86% reporting very good/fairly good health, respectively).
population_specificity: 79 stroke patients (mean age 64, 37% female) with good motor function (modified Rankin Scale ≤2) and capable of performing a 6-minute walking test at hospital discharge.
effective_dosage: Daily mobile phone instructional text messages to perform regular outdoor walking and functional leg exercises.
